chunks.original_text: 天地开辟已来，凶气不绝，绝者而后复起，何也？ 夫寿命，天之重宝也。 所以私有德，不可伪致。 欲知其宝，乃天地六合，八远万物，都得无所冤结，悉大喜，乃得增寿也。 一事不悦，辄有伤死亡者。 凡人之行，或有力行善，反常得恶； 或有力行恶，反得善。 因自言为贤者，非也。 力行善反得恶者，是承负先人之过，流灾前后，积来害此人也。 其行恶反得善者，是先人深有积畜大功，来流及此人也。 能行大功，万万倍之，先人虽有余殃，不能及此人也。 因复过去，流其后世成承。 五祖一小周，十世而一反初。 或有小行善，不能厌囹圄，其先人流恶，承负之灾中，世灭绝无后，诚冤哉。 承负者，天有三部，帝王三万岁相流，臣承负三千岁，民三百岁，皆承负相及，一伏一起，随人政衰盛不绝。 今能法此，以天上皇治而断绝，深思之而勿忘。 凡人有三寿，应三气，太阳、太阴、中和之命也。 上寿一百二十，中寿八十，下寿六十。 百二十者，应天大历，一岁竟终天地界也。 八十者，应阴阳分别八偶等应地，分别应地，分别万物，死者去，生者留。 六十者，应中和气，得六月遁卦。 遁者逃亡也，故主死生之会也。 如行善不止，过此寿，谓之度世。 行恶不止，不及三寿，皆夭也。 胞胎及未成人而死者，谓之无辜承负先人之过。 多头疾者，天气不悦也。 多足疾者，地气不悦也。 多五内疾者，是五行气战也。 多病四肢者，四时气不和也。 多病聋盲者，三光失度也。 多病寒热者，阴阳气忿争也。 多病愦乱者，万物失所也。 多病鬼物者，天地神灵怒也。 多病温而死者，太阳气杀也。 多病寒死者，太阴气害也。 多病卒死者，刑气太急也。 多病气胀或少气者，八节乖错也。 今天地阴阳，内独尽失其所，故病害万物。 帝王其治不和，水旱无常，盗贼数起，反更急其刑罚，或增之重益纷纷，连结不解，民皆上呼天，县官治乖乱，失节无常，万物失伤，上感动苍天，三光勃乱多变，列星乱行，故与至道可以救之者也，吾知天意不欺子也。 天威一发，不可禁也。 获罪于天，令人夭死。 初天地开辟自太，圣人各通达于一面，诚真知之，不复有疑也。 故能各作一大业，令后世修之，无有过误也。 故圣人尚各长于一大业，不能必知天道，故各异其德。 比若天，而况及人乎。 天地各长于一，故天长于高而清明，地长于下而重浊，中和长养万物也。 犹不能兼，而况凡人乎。 亥为天地西北极也，巳为天地东南极也，亥寒不以时收闭，来年巳反伤。 子乃天地之北极也，午为天地之南极也。 子今冬不善顺藏，午反承负而亡也。 丑乃天地东北极也，未乃天地西南极也。 丑不以时且生，六月反被其刑。 天地性运，皆如此矣。 今帝王居百重之内，其用道德，仁善万里，百姓蒙其恩。 父为慈，子为孝，家足人给，不为邪恶。 帝王居内，失其道德，万里之外，民臣失其职，是皆相去远万万里，其由一也。 习善言，不若习行于身也。 真人问神人：吾生不知可谓何等而常喜乎？ 神人言：子犹观昔者博大真人邪？ 所以先生而后老者，以其废邪人而独好真道，真道常保而邪者消。 凡人尽困穷，而我独长存，即是常喜也。 昭昭独乐，何忿之哉，卒为不能长生，当奈何？
chunks.translated_text:
Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, baleful qi has never ceased—once cut off, it later arises again. Why is this? Lifespan is Heaven’s most precious treasure. It is bestowed through private virtue and cannot be falsely attained. To know this treasure: when the six directions of Heaven and Earth, the eight distant realms, and the myriad things all remain free of grievance and entanglement, all rejoice greatly—only then is longevity increased. If even one matter brings displeasure, it immediately harms and brings death.

In human conduct, some strive to do good yet often meet with misfortune; others strive to do evil yet often meet with fortune. Those who claim themselves worthy are mistaken. Those who strive to do good yet meet misfortune bear the inherited burdens of their ancestors’ transgressions, as disasters flow forward and backward, accumulating to harm them. Those who do evil yet meet with fortune inherit the deep accumulations of their ancestors’ great merits, which flow to benefit them. If one performs great merits ten thousand times over, even if their ancestors left lingering misfortunes, these cannot reach them. Instead, the merits pass onward, flowing to their descendants as inherited blessings.

Five generations form a small cycle, and after ten generations, the effects return to their origin. Some perform minor good deeds yet cannot escape imprisonment; their ancestors’ flowing evils and inherited burdens strike them, cutting off their line and leaving no descendants—truly a grievous wrong.

Inherited burdens are divided into three celestial ranks: the Emperor’s burdens flow for thirty thousand years, ministers’ for three thousand years, and the common people’s for three hundred years. All bear and pass on these burdens in succession, rising and falling with the decline and flourishing of governance, never ceasing. If one now follows this principle, modeling governance on the Heavenly August Emperor to sever these burdens, they must ponder deeply and never forget.

Humans possess three lifespans, corresponding to three qi: the life of Great Yang, Great Yin, and the Harmonious Center. The upper lifespan is one hundred twenty years, the middle eighty, and the lower sixty. One hundred twenty corresponds to Heaven’s great reckoning, completing the boundary of Heaven and Earth in a single year. Eighty corresponds to the division of Yin and Yang, the eight pairs that align with Earth, distinguishing the myriad things—those that die depart, while those that live remain. Sixty corresponds to the qi of the Harmonious Center, attaining the hexagram *Dun* in the sixth month. *Dun* means escape and disappearance, thus governing the meeting of life and death.

If one ceaselessly practices good, surpassing these lifespans, it is called transcending the world. If one ceaselessly practices evil, falling short of these three lifespans, it is called premature death. Those who die in the womb or before maturity bear the innocent inherited burdens of their ancestors’ transgressions.

Those with frequent head ailments suffer from Heaven’s displeasure. Those with frequent foot ailments suffer from Earth’s displeasure. Those with frequent internal organ illnesses suffer from the warring qi of the five phases. Those with frequent limb ailments suffer from the disharmony of the four seasons’ qi. Those with frequent deafness and blindness suffer from the three luminaries losing their proper measure. Those with frequent chills and fevers suffer from the contention of Yin and Yang qi. Those with frequent confusion and disorder suffer from the myriad things losing their place. Those with frequent afflictions by ghosts and spirits suffer from the anger of Heaven and Earth’s deities. Those who often die of warmth-related illnesses are slain by Great Yang qi. Those who often die of cold are harmed by Great Yin qi. Those who often die suddenly are struck by excessively harsh punitive qi. Those who often suffer from bloating or shortness of breath suffer from the discord of the eight solar terms.

Now, Heaven and Earth’s Yin and Yang have entirely lost their proper places, thus harming the myriad things. If the Emperor’s governance is disharmonious, floods and droughts occur without pattern, bandits arise frequently, and punishments are made harsher—yet this only increases chaos, entangling and unresolved. The people all cry out to Heaven, while the court’s governance is disordered, losing its rhythm and constancy. The myriad things are harmed, moving even the Azure Heaven above. The three luminaries rage and change erratically, the constellations move in disorder—thus, only the utmost Dao can save them. I know Heaven’s intent does not deceive you.

Heaven’s might, once unleashed, cannot be restrained. To incur guilt before Heaven is to invite premature death.

From the opening of Heaven and Earth since the Great Beginning, sages each comprehended one aspect with perfect clarity, knowing it truly without doubt. Thus, each established one great enterprise, enabling later generations to cultivate it without error. Therefore, sages each excelled in one great enterprise yet could not fully know the Dao of Heaven—hence, their virtues differed. This is like Heaven and Earth: how much more so for humans? Heaven and Earth each excel in one aspect: Heaven excels in height and clarity, Earth in depth and turbidity, while the Harmonious Center nurtures the myriad things. Even they cannot encompass all—how much less can ordinary people?

*Hai* is the northwest extreme of Heaven and Earth; *Si* is the southeast extreme. If *Hai*’s cold does not close in due time, the following year’s *Si* will be harmed in return. *Zi* is the north extreme of Heaven and Earth; *Wu* is the south extreme. If this winter’s *Zi* does not properly store and conceal, *Wu* will bear the inherited burden and perish in return. *Chou* is the northeast extreme of Heaven and Earth; *Wei* is the southwest extreme. If *Chou* does not timely bring forth life, the sixth month will suffer its punishment in return. The nature and movement of Heaven and Earth are all thus.

Now, if the Emperor dwells within the hundredfold layers, governing with virtue and benevolence, his grace extends ten thousand *li*, and the people receive his favor. Fathers are kind, children filial; households are sufficient, and people do not turn to wickedness. If the Emperor within loses his virtue, beyond ten thousand *li*, officials and people lose their proper roles—though they are separated by countless *li*, the cause is one.

Practicing good words is not as effective as practicing good conduct in oneself.

The Perfected One asked the Divine Person: “In my life, what can I do to always be joyful?”

The Divine Person replied: “Do you recall the ancient, vast Perfected One? The reason he aged after others was that he abandoned the depraved and solely cherished the true Dao. The true Dao is constantly preserved, while the depraved vanish. While all people suffer hardship, I alone endure—this is constant joy. Shining brightly and rejoicing alone, what resentment could there be? Even if one ultimately cannot attain long life, what can be done?”

chunks.original_text: 神人言：积习近成，思善近生。 夫道者，乃无极之经也。 前古神人治之，以真人为臣，以治其民，故民不知上之有天子也，而以道自然无为自治。 其次真人为治，以仙人为臣，不见其民，时将知有天子也，闻其教敕而尊其主也。 其次仙人为治，以道人为臣，其治学微有刑被法令彰也，而民心动而有畏惧，巧诈将生也。 其次霸治，不详择其臣，民多冤而乱生焉，去治渐远，去乱惭近，不可复制也。 是故思神致神，思真致真，思仙致仙，思道致道，思智致智。 圣人之精思贤人，致贤人之神来佑之，思邪致愚人之鬼来惑之。 人可思念，皆有可致，在可思者优劣而已。 故上士为君，乃思神真； 中士为君，乃心通而多智； 下士为君，无可能思，随命可为。 真人问：何以知帝王思善思恶邪？ 神人言：易知邪。 帝王思仁善者，瑞应独为其出，图书独为其生，帝王仁明生于木火，武智生于金水，柔和生土。 天之垂象，无误者也。 真人问：古者特生之图奇方，谁当得者乎？ 其吏民得之献王者。 帝王者时气即为和良，政治益明，道术贤哲出为辅弼之，帝王之道，日强盛矣。 夷狄灭息，垂拱而治，刑罚自绝，民无兵革，帝王思善之证，可不知哉？ 不睹其人，已知之矣。 真人问：神人何以能知此乎？ 神人言：以无声致之。 君欲仁好生，象天道也； 臣欲柔而顺好养，法地道也，即善应出矣。 故天地不语而长存，其治独神，神灵不语而长仙，皆以内明而外暗，故为万道之端。 夫神灵出入，无有穴窠，清静而无声，安枕而卧，神光自生，安得不吉乐之哉。 夫用口多者竭其精，用力多者苦其形，用武多者贼其身，此者凶祸所生也。 子慎吾之言，不可妄思。 思之善或有德，思之恶还自贼，安危之间，相错若发髻，子戒之无杂思也。 夫人失道命即绝，审知道意命可活，勉养子精，无自煎也。 学得明师事之，祸乱不得发也。 真人不敢失神人之辞也。 神人言：夫学者各为其身，不为他人也。 故当各自爱而自亲，学道积久，成神真也，与众绝殊，是其言也。 真人问：何以知道效乎？ 神人曰：决之於明师，行之於身，身变形易，与神道同门，与真为邻，与神人同户，求之子身，何不睹患，其失道意，反求之四野，索之不得，便至穷老矣。 遂离其根，言天下无道也，常独愁苦，离其根，是为大灾。 大人失之不能平其治，中士失之乱其君，仁人失之无从为贤，小人失之灭其身。 古之贤圣所行，与今同耳。 古之小人所穷，亦与今同耳，明证若此。 真人问：何以知人将兴将衰乎？ 神人言：大人将兴，奇文出，贤者助之为治。 家人将兴，求者得生，其子善可知矣。 真人问：何以致是贤者？ 神人言：皆以思也，精思不止，其事皆来。 神哉，道之为治，可不力行哉。 神人言：三纲六纪所以能长吉者，以其守道也，不失其治，故常吉。 天之寿命，不夺人之愿。 木性仁，思仁故致东方，东方主仁。 五方皆如斯也。 天下之事，各从其类，故帝王思靖，其治亦静，以类召也。 古之学者，效之於身； 今之学者，反效之於人。 古之学者以安身，今之学者浮华文，不积精於身，反积精於文，是为不知其根矣。 太平经钞乙部卷之二竟 太平经钞丙部卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
The Divine Person said: “Accumulated practice nears completion; thoughts of goodness nears life. The Dao is the scripture of the boundless. In ancient times, the Divine Persons governed, taking Perfected Ones as ministers to rule the people—thus the people knew not that above them there was an emperor, and through the Dao’s natural non-action, they governed themselves. Next, the Perfected Ones governed, taking Immortals as ministers; though they did not see the people, the people occasionally knew there was an emperor, hearing his teachings and revering their lord. Next, the Immortals governed, taking Daoists as ministers; their rule bore slight traces of punishment and law, and the people’s hearts stirred with fear, giving rise to cunning and deceit. Next came hegemonic rule, where ministers were not carefully chosen, the people suffered many grievances, and chaos arose. As governance receded, disorder drew near, and control could no longer be restored.

Thus, to think of the divine is to summon the divine; to think of the Perfected is to summon the Perfected; to think of the Immortal is to summon the Immortal; to think of the Dao is to summon the Dao; to think of wisdom is to summon wisdom. When the sage’s concentrated thoughts turn to the worthy, the spirit of the worthy comes to aid him; when thoughts turn to depravity, the ghosts of fools come to delude him. Whatever a person may contemplate can be summoned—only the excellence or inferiority of what is thought differs.

Therefore, when a superior scholar becomes ruler, he thinks of the divine and Perfected; when a middling scholar becomes ruler, his mind is penetrating and full of wisdom; when an inferior scholar becomes ruler, he cannot think deeply and merely follows fate as it unfolds.

The Perfected One asked: “How can one know whether an emperor’s thoughts are good or evil?”

The Divine Person replied: “It is easily known. When an emperor thinks of benevolence and goodness, auspicious signs appear solely for him, and prophetic texts arise solely for him. Emperors of benevolence and clarity are born of Wood and Fire; those of martial wisdom are born of Metal and Water; those of gentleness and harmony are born of Earth. Heaven’s descending omens never err.”

The Perfected One asked: “In ancient times, extraordinary prophetic texts and rare methods—who was worthy to receive them?”

“Officials and commoners who obtained them presented them to their king. When the emperor’s *qi* of the times was harmonious and good, governance grew ever clearer, Daoist arts and worthy sages emerged to assist him, and the emperor’s Way daily grew stronger. The barbarians were pacified and vanished; he governed with folded arms, punishments ceased of themselves, and the people knew no warfare. Is this not proof of an emperor’s good thoughts? Even without seeing the man, one already knows.”

The Perfected One asked: “How does the Divine Person know this?”

The Divine Person said: “By attaining it without sound. When the ruler desires benevolence and cherishes life, he models the Way of Heaven; when ministers desire gentleness, compliance, and nurturing, they follow the Way of Earth—then good omens appear. Thus Heaven and Earth do not speak yet endure forever; their governance is uniquely divine. The divine and numinous do not speak yet attain long life as Immortals—all through inner illumination and outer obscurity, which is the origin of the ten thousand Ways.

The divine and numinous move in and out without lairs or nests; pure and tranquil, without sound, they lie at ease upon their pillows, and their spiritual radiance arises of itself. How could this not be joyous and auspicious? Those who use their mouths excessively deplete their essence; those who exert their strength excessively weary their bodies; those who employ force excessively harm themselves—from these arise misfortune and calamity. Heed my words and do not think recklessly. Good thoughts may bring virtue, but evil thoughts return to harm oneself. Between safety and danger, the difference is as fine as a hair’s breadth—beware of mixed thoughts.

When a person loses the Dao, their fate is cut off; when one truly understands the Dao’s intent, life may be preserved. Strive to nurture your essence and do not consume yourself. Study under an enlightened teacher, and misfortune and chaos will not arise.”

The Perfected One dared not disregard the Divine Person’s words.

The Divine Person said: “Learners act for themselves, not for others. Thus each should cherish and draw near to themselves. Through long accumulation in studying the Dao, one becomes a divine Perfected One, utterly distinct from the multitude—such are my words.”

The Perfected One asked: “How can one know the efficacy of the Dao?”

The Divine Person said: “Resolve it through an enlightened teacher, practice it in oneself. The body transforms and changes form, entering the same gate as the divine Way, becoming neighbors with the Perfected, sharing a door with the Divine Person. Seek it within yourself—how could misfortune be seen? If one loses the Dao’s intent and instead seeks it in the four wilds, searching in vain, one reaches old age in poverty. Thus severed from the root, one claims the world has no Dao, ever alone in sorrow and suffering—this is the greatest calamity. The great person, losing it, cannot level their governance; the middling scholar, losing it, brings chaos to their lord; the benevolent person, losing it, has no way to act as a worthy; the petty person, losing it, destroys themselves. The conduct of the ancient worthies and sages is the same as today’s; the ruin of the ancient petty people is also the same as today’s—clear evidence indeed.”

The Perfected One asked: “How can one know whether a person will rise or fall?”

The Divine Person said: “When a great person is about to rise, extraordinary texts appear, and the worthy assist in governance. When a household is about to rise, those who seek will find life, and the goodness of their descendants can be known.”

The Perfected One asked: “How can one summon such worthies?”

The Divine Person said: “All through thought. With unceasing concentrated thought, all things come. How wondrous is the Dao’s governance—can one not strive to practice it?”

The Divine Person said: “The Three Bonds and Six Disciplines endure in good fortune because they uphold the Dao and do not lose their governance—thus they are always auspicious. Heaven’s lifespan does not override human wishes. The nature of Wood is benevolence; thinking of benevolence thus summons the East, for the East governs benevolence. The five directions are all like this. All matters under Heaven follow their kind—thus when an emperor thinks of tranquility, his governance is also tranquil, for like calls to like.

The ancients who studied emulated it in themselves; today’s scholars emulate it in others. The ancients studied to secure themselves; today’s scholars pursue superficial ornamentation, not accumulating essence in themselves but accumulating essence in texts—this is to be ignorant of the root.”

*Excerpts from the Tai Ping Jing, Concluding Section of Scroll Two of the Yi Division*
*Beginning of Scroll Three of the Bing Division of the Tai Ping Jing*

“In my life, what can I do to always be joyful?”

The Divine Person replied: “Do you recall the ancient, vast Perfected One? The reason he aged after others was that he abandoned the depraved and solely cherished the true Dao. The true Dao is constantly preserved, while the depraved vanish. While all people suffer hardship, I alone endure—this is constant joy. Shining brightly and rejoicing alone, what resentment could there be? Even if one ultimately cannot attain long life, what can be done?”

chunks.original_text: 分别贫富，君王行之立吉，禁人断绝地统，以兴男女，平复王政。 天下何者称富，何者称贫？ 然，多有者为富，少有者为贫。 然子言是也，又实非也。 今邪伪盗贼，岂可为富也。 今凡人多，帝王少，岂可谓贫邪。 富之为言，毕备足矣。 天以凡物悉生为富足，故上皇炁出，万二千物异生，名为富足。 中皇物减少，不能备足万二千物，故称小贫。 下皇物复少於中皇，为大贫。 无瑞应，善物不生，极下贫。 万物俱出，地养之不中伤，为地富，不能养物为大贫。 天为父，地为母，此父母贫极，则其子日贫矣。 古者帝王以道治天下，能致万二千物，为上富君。 善物不足三分之二，为中富君。 三分之一，为下富君。 琦物不生，下贫之君也。 古者有道帝王，深居幽室而思道德，而万物自足，岂不乐哉。 帝王行道者，天神助其化； 行德者，地神助其治； 行中和者，人神助其治； 行文者，隐欺之阶也。 故欺神助之，其治逆於天心，而伤善人。 武治天下，以刑杀服人，盗贼市刑杀害也。 为帝王法之本意，以类相报，天以好生，故称君父也。 地以宁静好养万物，故称母也。 用心仁爱万物，故称仁也。 此二者善，故称为师长。 大顺天地，合阴阳，男女无冤结者，致时雨降，二炁和，地生万物。 帝王之道治，立致太平。 夫贞男不施，贞女不化，阴阳不交，灭绝世类，二人共绝天地之统，贪虚伪之名，反无后世，失其实核，此天下大害也。 天若守贞，即时雨不降； 地若守贞，即万物不生。 不施不生，其害大矣。 天将兴雨，先必有风云，使人知之。 所以然者，欲令收藏。 今太平炁当欲至，恐人为恶不止，故先觉之，令帝王当法象天地，先视善道王事。 解承负诀。 天地开辟以来，帝王大臣人民承负，为此事出教也。 凡自帝王大臣人民，有承负过责，流及后世，皆由不能善养，失其纪纲，故有承负之责也。 比若父母失道德，有过於乡里，后子孙必被乡里所害，此乃承负之验也。 古者帝王大臣人民，各知自养之道，安有承负哉。 天不欺人，种禾得禾，种麦得麦，在用力多少，其稼善恶。 为皇天解承负之仇，为后土解承负之殃，为帝王解承负之厄，为万民解承负之过，为万二千物解承负之责。 欲解承负之责，莫如守一，守一久，天将怜之。 一者天之纪纲，万物之本也。 思其本，流及其末。 古者圣人将有作也，仰占天文，俯察地理，明其本末，睹其明效。 天下之人有四穷，何谓也？ 谓子本生於父母，少年之时，思其父母不能去，是一穷也； 及其大自胜，女欲嫁，男欲娶，不能胜其情欲，因相爱不能相离，是二穷也； 既相爱，即生子，夫妇老长，颜色不可爱，其子少可爱，又当见养，是三穷也； 其子只大，可无养身，便自老长，不解行，是四穷也。 四穷之后，能得明师，思虑守道上可。 高才有天命者，或得度世，其次或得寿，其次可得须臾乐其身。 魂魄居地下，为其复乐。 何谓也？ 地下悉得新死之入，悉问其生时所作所更，因定明籍，因其所作而责之。 故子不可不预防安危。 人君当思太平，得天之心，魂魄神常与炁合。 其不能平其治者，不合天心，不得天意，谓无功於天，终即魂魄神独责於地下，以恶气合。 是古上圣之君顶知此，故努力为善。

Distinguishing between poverty and wealth, when the ruler enacts this, it establishes good fortune—prohibiting the severance of the earth’s lineage to promote the flourishing of men and women, thereby restoring the king’s governance. What is called wealth in the world? What is called poverty? Indeed, those who possess much are wealthy, and those who possess little are poor. Yet your words, while correct, are also fundamentally untrue. Can the deceitful, the false, the thieves, and the bandits truly be called wealthy? Today, the common people are many, and the emperors few—how can this be called poverty?

Wealth, in its meaning, is complete sufficiency. Heaven deems all things fully born as wealth and sufficiency. Thus, in the era of the Upper August, qi emerged, and the twelve thousand things were born in diversity—this was called wealth and sufficiency. In the era of the Middle August, things diminished and could not fully sustain the twelve thousand things, thus it was called minor poverty. In the era of the Lower August, things were even fewer than in the Middle August—this was called great poverty. Without auspicious responses, when good things do not arise, it is extreme poverty. When all things emerge and the earth nourishes them without harm, this is the earth’s wealth; when it cannot nourish things, it is great poverty.

Heaven is the father, earth the mother—when these parents reach extreme poverty, their children grow poorer by the day. In ancient times, the emperor who governed the world with the Dao could bring forth the twelve thousand things—this was the ruler of supreme wealth. When good things fell short by two-thirds, it was the ruler of middle wealth; by one-third, the ruler of lesser wealth. When rare things did not arise, it was the ruler of extreme poverty.

The ancient emperors of the Dao dwelled in seclusion, contemplating virtue and power, and the myriad things were naturally sufficient—was this not joyous? When the emperor practices the Dao, the celestial spirits aid his transformation; when he practices virtue, the earthly spirits aid his governance; when he practices harmony, the human spirits aid his rule; but when he practices ornamentation, it becomes the path of hidden deceit. Thus, deceitful spirits assist him, and his governance runs counter to the will of Heaven, harming the good.

Ruling the world with military force, subduing people through punishment and execution, is like thieves and bandits inflicting harm through execution. The original intent of the emperor’s laws is retribution by kind. Heaven delights in giving life, thus it is called the Lord and Father. Earth delights in tranquility and nourishing the myriad things, thus it is called the Mother. Using the heart to cherish and love all things—this is called benevolence. These two are good, thus they are called teachers and elders.

Greatly aligning with Heaven and Earth, harmonizing yin and yang, with no grievances between men and women, brings timely rain, harmonizes the two qi, and the earth gives birth to the myriad things. When the emperor’s Dao governs, it swiftly brings Great Peace.

If chaste men do not bestow and chaste women do not transform, yin and yang do not unite, and the lineage of the world is extinguished—when two people together sever the lineage of Heaven and Earth, coveting hollow and false reputations, they leave no descendants, losing the true essence. This is the world’s greatest harm. If Heaven were to remain chaste, timely rain would not fall; if Earth were to remain chaste, the myriad things would not be born. Not bestowing, not giving birth—this harm is great indeed.

When Heaven is about to send rain, it first stirs wind and clouds so that people may know. The reason for this is to prompt them to gather and store. Now, as the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, fearing that people will not cease their evil, it first awakens them. The emperor should model himself on Heaven and Earth, first observing the virtuous Dao in royal affairs.

**The Method for Resolving Karmic Debt:**
Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, emperors, ministers, and the people have borne karmic debt, and this is why teachings have emerged. From emperors and ministers to the common people, all who bear karmic debt pass it to later generations—this is due to their inability to nurture goodness, losing their guiding principles, thus incurring karmic responsibility.

For example, if parents lose virtue and commit wrongs in their village, their descendants will surely be harmed by the village—this is the proof of karmic debt. In ancient times, emperors, ministers, and the people each knew the way to nurture themselves—how could there have been karmic debt?

Heaven does not deceive people: sow millet, and you reap millet; sow wheat, and you reap wheat. It depends on the effort expended, whether the harvest is good or bad. Resolving the enmity of karmic debt for the August Heaven, resolving the calamity of karmic debt for the Earth, resolving the distress of karmic debt for the emperor, resolving the transgressions of karmic debt for the myriad people, resolving the responsibility of karmic debt for the twelve thousand things—there is nothing better for resolving karmic debt than abiding by the One. If one abides by the One for long, Heaven will take pity.

The One is the guiding principle of Heaven and the root of the myriad things. Contemplate its root, and it will extend to its branches. When the sages of old were about to act, they observed the celestial patterns above and examined the earthly principles below, clarifying root and branch, witnessing their evident effects.

The people of the world have four hardships—what are they? A child, born of parents, in youth cannot leave their thoughts of their parents—this is the first hardship. When grown and self-reliant, a woman desires marriage, a man desires a wife, yet they cannot overcome their passions, and their love prevents separation—this is the second hardship. Once in love, they bear children; as husband and wife age, their appearance is no longer lovely, but their young children are lovable and must be raised—this is the third hardship. When the children grow, they no longer need to be raised, but the parents themselves age and do not understand how to conduct themselves—this is the fourth hardship.

After these four hardships, if one can find a wise teacher and contemplate guarding the Dao, it may yet be well. Those of high talent with heavenly mandate may transcend the world; the next may attain longevity; the next may briefly enjoy their bodies. When the hun and po reside beneath the earth, they may yet find joy. Why is this? Beneath the earth, all newly deceased arrive and are questioned about their deeds in life, their records clearly established, and they are held accountable for their actions. Thus, one must prepare in advance for safety and peril.

The ruler should contemplate Great Peace, aligning with the heart of Heaven, so that hun, po, and spirit constantly unite with qi. Those who cannot bring peace to their governance do not align with the heart of Heaven, do not gain Heaven’s favor, and are deemed to have no merit before Heaven. In the end, their hun, po, and spirit will be held solely accountable beneath the earth, uniting with evil qi.

The ancient supreme sage-rulers understood this well, thus they exerted themselves to do good.

chunks.original_text: 愚人不深计，故生亦有谴谪於天，死亦有谴谪於地，可不骇哉。 速传吾书，使天下之人得行之，俱思其身定精，念合於大道，且自知过所从来，即承负之责除矣。 天地大喜，复反上古而倍矣。 天一也，反行地二，其意何也？ 今地二，反行人三，何也？ 夫地为天使，人为地使，故天悦喜，即使今地上万物大喜悦。 地虽养物也，善即民居善，此其相使明效也。 夫治乱者，犹太多端，不得天之心，当反还其根本。 夫人言太多，亦致乱，若本根，何患哉。 故一言而成者，本也； 再言而止者，成章句也； 三言而止，反成解难也； 将远真故有解难也； 四言而止，反成文辞也； 五言而止，反成伪也； 六言而止，反成败也； 七言而止，反成破也； 八言而止，反成离散远道，远复远也； 九言而止，反成大乱； 十言而止，反成灭毁。 故终至十而改，更相传而败也。 夫凡事毁者当反本，故反守一以为元首。 是故数起於一，终於十，自然治乱之数也。 是故古者圣人问事，初一占者，其吉凶是也，守其本，乃天神下告也。 再卜占者，地神出告也。 三卜占者，人神出告之也。 过此而下者，皆欺人，不可占，故卦数即不中也。 人间辞多不珍。 善哉。 天数起於一，终於十，何也？ 天一也，下与地二也，阴阳具而共生。 万物始萌兆，元炁起於子，转东北布根於角，转在东方生出达，转在东南而悉生枝叶，转在南方而茂盛，转在西方而成熟，转在西北而终。 物终，故当更始，故为亥，二人共抱一，为三皇初。 是故亥者，核也，乃始凝核也，故水始凝於十月。 壬者，任也，巳任必滋日益巨。 故子者，滋也，三而得阴阳中和炁，都具成而更反初起，故复本名为甲子。 天道生物，当周流俱具，四时五行之炁，乃能成也。 故本於天地，周流八方，故数终於十。 问：帝王诸侯之为治，何者最善哉？ 曰：广哀不伤，如天之行，最善。 夫治莫若大象天也，虽然，当有次第。 何谓也？ 夫人最善，莫如乐生，急急若渴，乃后可也。 其次乐成他人善，如己之善。 其次莫若人施，见人贫乏，谓其愁心，比若忧饥寒乃可也。 其次莫若设法，但惧而置之可也。 其次人有大罪，莫若於治，不陷於罪过乃可也。 其次人有过触犯事，不可奈何，能不使及其家与比伍，乃可也。 其次罪及比伍，愿指有罪者，慎无绝嗣也。 人者，天地神明之统，伤败天地之体，其为祸深矣。 无为子孙承负之厄，常思太平，以消刑格也。 吾为天地谭，为上德君制作，可以除天地开辟已来承负之厄。 会议不敢忘语，必得怨於皇天后土，又承负於上贤明道德之君，其为罪深大矣。 拘校上古中古下古道书，集众贤共读，视古今诸道文。 如一卷得一善守，如得一善诀，便随事书记之。 一卷一善，十卷得十善，百卷得百善，千卷得千善，万卷得万善，亿卷得亿善。 随而书之，出众贤共议，去复重，因此要文编之以究意，深知古今天地人万物之精意，简说九人意，其无冤者乎。 王治因喜，解其先王之承负。 夫人，万物之长也。 其无形委炁之神人，职在治元炁。 大神人职在治天，真人职在治地，仙人职在治四时，大道人职在治五行，圣人职在治阴阳，贤人职在治文书皆受语，凡人职在治草木五谷，奴婢职在治财货。
chunks.translated_text:
The foolish do not ponder deeply, thus in life they incur Heaven’s reproach, and in death they incur Earth’s reproach—how can this not be terrifying? Swiftly transmit my writings so that all under Heaven may practice them, each reflecting on their own essence, their thoughts aligning with the Great Dao. Once they recognize the origin of their transgressions, the burden of inherited responsibility shall be lifted. Heaven and Earth will rejoice greatly, reverting to the ancient age and doubling its blessings.

Heaven is One, yet it acts through Earth as Two—what is the meaning of this? Now Earth is Two, yet it acts through Man as Three—why is this? Earth serves as Heaven’s agent, and Man serves as Earth’s agent. Thus, when Heaven is pleased, it immediately causes all things upon Earth to rejoice. Though Earth nurtures all beings, if goodness prevails, the people dwell in goodness—this is the clear effect of their mutual agency.

The causes of order and chaos are manifold. Those who do not align with Heaven’s heart must return to their root. When human speech proliferates, it too leads to chaos. But if one returns to the root, what cause for concern is there?

Thus, a single word that achieves its purpose is the root. A second word that suffices forms a coherent phrase. A third word that suffices instead becomes an explanation of difficulties, for the farther one strays from truth, the more explanations are needed. A fourth word that suffices instead becomes literary embellishment. A fifth word that suffices instead becomes falsehood. A sixth word that suffices instead leads to failure. A seventh word that suffices instead leads to ruin. An eighth word that suffices instead leads to separation and estrangement, growing ever more distant. A ninth word that suffices instead leads to great chaos. A tenth word that suffices instead leads to destruction and annihilation. Thus, upon reaching ten, one must reform, for further transmission only brings ruin.

In all matters, when destruction occurs, one must return to the root. Therefore, return and hold fast to the One as the origin. Hence, numbers begin with One and end with Ten—this is the natural principle governing order and chaos.

Thus, the sages of antiquity, when consulting the oracle, first divined once: its auspice or inauspice was decisive. By holding to the root, the celestial spirits would descend with their message. A second divination summoned the earthly spirits to speak. A third divination summoned the human spirits to speak. Beyond this, all is deception, unworthy of divination, and the hexagrams lose their accuracy. Human discourse, when excessive, is not to be treasured.

How excellent! The celestial numbers begin with One and end with Ten—why is this? Heaven is One, and below it, Earth is Two. Yin and Yang unite to give birth to all things. The first signs of life emerge as primordial qi arises in the *zi* hour, turns northeast to spread roots in the *jiao* constellation, then moves east to sprout and grow, shifts southeast to develop branches and leaves, turns south to flourish, moves west to ripen, and turns northwest to reach completion. When things come to an end, they must begin anew, thus the *hai* hour: two embracing one, the beginning of the Three Sovereigns. Therefore, *hai* is the kernel, the first coagulation of the seed—hence water begins to congeal in the tenth month. *Ren* means "to bear," for what is borne must grow day by day. Thus, *zi* means "to multiply." When Three achieves the harmony of Yin and Yang’s qi, all is complete, and it returns to the beginning, hence the name *jiazi*. The Dao of Heaven in generating things must circulate fully, uniting the qi of the four seasons and five phases to bring them to completion. Thus, it is rooted in Heaven and Earth, circulating through the eight directions, and the numbers end at Ten.

Question: Of the governance of emperors and feudal lords, which is most excellent?
Answer: To extend compassion without harm, acting as Heaven does—this is most excellent. In governance, nothing surpasses emulating the great image of Heaven. Yet there must be an order of priority. What does this mean?

The highest good is to cherish life, desiring it as urgently as one craves water—only then is it acceptable. Next is to delight in the goodness of others as if it were one’s own. Next is to bestow upon others: when seeing someone in poverty, one should feel their sorrow as keenly as if suffering hunger and cold. Next is to establish laws, ensuring that fear alone deters transgression. Next, for those guilty of grave crimes, governance should prevent them from falling into wrongdoing. Next, when someone commits an offense, if unavoidable, ensure it does not implicate their family or neighbors. Next, if the offense extends to neighbors, one should identify the guilty party while taking care not to sever their lineage. Humans are the stewards of Heaven, Earth, and the divine luminaries. To harm and disrupt the body of Heaven and Earth is to invite profound calamity. Do not bring the burden of inherited responsibility upon descendants. Constantly aspire to Great Peace to dissolve the obstructions of punishment.

I expound for Heaven and Earth, composing this for rulers of supreme virtue, that they may eliminate the burdens of inherited responsibility since the opening of Heaven and Earth. If this discourse is neglected, one will surely incur the resentment of the August Heaven and the Sacred Earth, and bear the burden of responsibility before the enlightened and virtuous rulers of the past—such a transgression would be grave indeed.

I have collated and examined the Daoist scriptures of high, middle, and low antiquity, gathering the wise to read them together and survey the texts of Dao from past and present. If one scripture yields one good precept, record it. If one good technique is found, note it down as the matter arises. One scripture yields one goodness, ten scriptures yield ten goodnesses, a hundred yield a hundred, a thousand yield a thousand, ten thousand yield ten thousand, and a hundred million yield a hundred million goodnesses. Record them accordingly, then assemble the wise to deliberate, removing redundancies. From this, compile the essential texts to fully grasp the profound intent of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things in ancient and modern times. Condensing the insights of nine sages—could there be any injustice?

The king’s governance, rejoicing in this, will resolve the inherited burdens of his predecessors. Humans are the foremost of the myriad things. The formless spirit-people, composed of refined qi, are charged with governing primordial qi. The great spirit-people govern Heaven, the perfected people govern Earth, the immortals govern the four seasons, the great Daoists govern the five phases, the sages govern Yin and Yang, the worthies govern documents and receive teachings, ordinary people govern plants and the five grains, and servants govern wealth and goods.
chunks.overlap_context:
The ruler should contemplate Great Peace, aligning with the heart of Heaven, so that hun, po, and spirit constantly unite with qi. Those who cannot bring peace to their governance do not align with the heart of Heaven, do not gain Heaven’s favor, and are deemed to have no merit before Heaven. In the end, their hun, po, and spirit will be held solely accountable beneath the earth, uniting with evil qi.

The ancient supreme sage-rulers understood this well, thus they exerted themselves to do good.

chunks.original_text: 夫皇天署职，不夺其心，各从其类，不误也。 反之为大害。 故置署天之凡民，皆当顺此。 古者圣人深承知此，不失天意，得天心也。 言九人各易治，而得天心，九炁合和，故能致太平也。 此九事迭相成生，一炁不和，辄有不至者。 元炁不和，无形神人不来至。 天炁不和，大神人不来至。 地炁不和，真人不来至。 四时不和，仙人不来至。 五行不和，大道人不来至。 阴阳不和，圣人不来至。 万物不和，凡民乱，货财少，奴婢逃亡。 凡事失职，为害若此。 得此九人，能消万世帝王承负之灾。 此九人上极无刑，下极奴婢，各调一炁。 故上士修道，先当食炁，是欲与元炁和合，当茅室斋戒，不睹邪恶，日炼其形，无夺其欲，能出入无间，上助仙真元炁天治也。 是为神士，为天之吏也。 无禁无止，诚能就之，名天士，简阅善人，天大喜，还为人利也。 夫得道去世，虽不时目下之用，而能和调阴阳炁，以利万物。 古者帝王祭天上诸神，为此神吏也。 凡圣皆有极，为无形神人，下极为奴婢。 神人者，乘炁而行，故人有炁即有神，炁绝即神亡。 皇天之明要证也。 所以明敕人君之治，得失之效。
chunks.translated_text:
Heaven appoints offices according to nature, never overriding their inherent inclinations—each follows its kind without error. To act contrary invites great harm. Thus, all the common people under Heaven’s charge must comply with this principle. The sages of antiquity deeply understood this, never deviating from Heaven’s intent, thereby gaining Heaven’s favor. The nine ranks each govern with ease, securing Heaven’s favor; when the nine qi harmonize, they bring about Great Peace. These nine matters mutually generate and complete one another—if even one qi fails to harmonize, some will not arrive. If primordial qi is disharmonious, the formless spirit-people will not come. If Heaven’s qi is disharmonious, the great spirit-people will not come. If Earth’s qi is disharmonious, the perfected people will not come. If the four seasons are disharmonious, the immortals will not come. If the five phases are disharmonious, the great Daoists will not come. If Yin and Yang are disharmonious, the sages will not come. If the myriad things are disharmonious, the common people will fall into chaos, goods and wealth will diminish, and servants will flee. When any office fails in its duty, the harm is thus. Obtaining these nine ranks can dispel the inherited burdens of ten thousand generations of kings. These nine ranks ascend to the formless spirit-people and descend to servants—each regulates a single qi.

Therefore, the superior scholar who cultivates the Dao must first consume qi, seeking to harmonize with primordial qi. He should fast in a thatched chamber, avoiding all evil, refining his form daily, and never yielding to desire. Thus, he may move freely between realms, aiding the immortals and perfected in governing Heaven’s primordial qi. Such is the divine scholar, an official of Heaven. Unrestrained and unbound, if he truly attains this, he is called a Heavenly Scholar. Heaven reviews the virtuous, rejoicing greatly, and in turn benefits humanity.

Though one who attains the Dao and departs this world may not serve an immediate purpose, he can harmonize Yin and Yang’s qi to benefit the myriad things. The ancient kings sacrificed to the celestial deities for the sake of these divine officials. All, from sages to servants, have their limits—the highest are the formless spirit-people, the lowest are servants. The spirit-people move by riding qi; thus, where there is qi, there is spirit, and when qi ceases, spirit perishes. This is the luminous decree of August Heaven, by which the governance of human rulers is judged, and the effects of success or failure are made manifest.

chunks.original_text: 夫刑德者，天地阴阳神治之明效，为万物人民法度。 故十一月，大德在初九，居地下，德时在室中，故内有炁，万物归之。 时形在上六，在四野，故外无炁而消也，外空万物，士众皆归，王德随之入黄泉之下。 十二月，德在九二之时，在丑，居土之中而未出达，时德在明堂，万物随德而上，未敢出见，上有刑也。 正月，寅德在九三，万物莫不随盛德，乐阅於地而生，时德居庭。 二月，德在九四，在卯巳，去地未及天，适在界上，德在门，故万物悉乐出窥於门也。 三月，盛德在九五辰上，及天之中，盛德时在外道巷，故万物悉出居外也。 四月，巳德在上九，到於六远八境，盛德八方，善炁阳炁，莫不响相应，扰扰生之属，去四室之野处。 时刑在万物之根，居内室，下室无物，而上茂盛也，莫不乐从德为治也，是治以德大明效。 今谨已闻用德，未闻用刑。 然。 五月刑在初六，在午地下，下内无炁，地下空，时刑在空中，内无物，皆居外。 六月，刑居六二，在未，居土之中，未出达也，时刑在明堂，时刑炁在内，德炁在外，扰扰之属，莫不乐露其身，归盛德也。 七月，刑六三，申之时，刑在庭，万物未敢入，固固乐居外。 八月，刑在六四，酉时，尚未及天界，时德在门，万物俱乐窥於门，乐入随德而还反也。 九月，刑在六五，在戌上及中，时刑在道巷，万物莫不旦死，因随德入藏，故内日兴，外者空亡。 十月，刑在上六，亥时，刑及六远八境四野，万物扰扰之属，莫不入藏逃，随德行到于明堂，蚑行之类，自怀居内，野外空无士众，是非好用刑罚者，见徒邪哉。 但心意内怀，以刑治其士众，辄日为衰少也。 五月，内怀一刑，一群众叛。 六月，内怀二刑，二群众叛。 七月，内怀三刑，三群众叛。 八月，内怀四刑，四群众叛。 九月，内怀五刑，五群众叛。 十月，内怀六刑，六方群众叛。 故外悉无物，皆逃於内，是明证效也。 故刑治者，外恭谨而内叛，故士众日少也。 是故十一月，内怀一德，一群众入。 十二月内怀二德，二群众入。 正月内怀三德，三群众入。 二月内怀四德，四群众入。 三月内怀五阳盛德，五群贤者入。 从四月内，六德万物并出见，莫不扰扰，中外归之，此天明堂法效也。 二月、八月，德与刑相半，故万物半伤於寒。 夫刑日伤杀，厌畏之，而不得众力。 古者圣人威人以道德，不以筋力刑罚也。 为垂象作法，为帝王立教令，可仪以治。 王道将兴，取象於德； 王道将衰，取象於刑。 夫为帝王制法度，先明天意，内明阴阳之道，即太平至矣。 天师乃与皇天后土常合精念，心与天地意深相得，比若重规合矩，失毛发之间也。 知天地常所忧，预得知天地之大忌讳者，何等也？ 天地神灵深大疾苦，恶人不顺不孝，何谓也？ 夫天地中和三炁，内共相与为一家，共养万物。 天者主生，称父； 地者主养，称母； 人者为治，称子。 子者，受命於父，恩养於母，为子乃敬事父而爱其母，何谓也？ 然父教有度数时节，故因四时而教生成。 恶人逆父之意，天炁失其政令，比若家人，父怒其子，父子不和，阴胜阳，下欺上，臣失其职，鬼物大兴。 天地之位，如人男女之别，其好恶皆同。 天者养人命，地者养人形。
chunks.translated_text:
The interplay of punishment and virtue is the manifest efficacy of Heaven and Earth’s governance through Yin and Yang spirits, serving as the model for all things and the people. Thus, in the eleventh month, great virtue resides in the *nine-one* position, dwelling beneath the earth. At this time, virtue abides within the chamber, so the inner realm possesses qi, and the myriad things return to it. The *six-four* position, situated in the four wilds, holds the outward form, so the outer realm lacks qi and dissipates. The outer expanse is empty of all things, and the multitudes of scholars and commoners all return, following the king’s virtue into the depths of the Yellow Springs.

In the twelfth month, virtue resides in the *nine-two* position, in the *chou* hour, dwelling within the earth’s center yet to emerge. At this time, virtue abides in the Bright Hall, and the myriad things follow virtue upward but dare not appear, for punishment looms above. In the first month, the *yin* hour, virtue resides in the *nine-three* position, and all things without exception follow its flourishing power, rejoicing in their emergence upon the earth. At this time, virtue dwells in the courtyard.

In the second month, virtue resides in the *nine-four* position, in the *mao* and *si* hours, neither fully departed from the earth nor yet reaching Heaven, but precisely at the boundary. Virtue abides at the gate, so all things delight in peering outward from the gate. In the third month, flourishing virtue resides in the *nine-five* position atop the *chen* hour, reaching the center of Heaven. At this time, virtue abides in the outer pathways, so all things emerge and dwell outside.

In the fourth month, the *si* hour, virtue resides in the *nine-six* position, extending to the six distant boundaries and eight frontiers. Flourishing virtue pervades the eight directions, and the auspicious qi of Yang responds in kind. The teeming living things depart from the four chambers and the wilds. At this time, punishment resides at the roots of the myriad things, dwelling within the inner chamber. The lower chamber is empty, while the upper flourishes, and none fail to delight in following virtue to govern. This is the great manifest efficacy of governance through virtue.

Now, I have heard of employing virtue but have not heard of employing punishment. Yet, in the fifth month, punishment resides in the *six-one* position, in the *wu* hour beneath the earth. The inner realm lacks qi, and the earth below is empty. At this time, punishment abides in the void, and the inner realm is empty of all things, which all dwell outside.

In the sixth month, punishment resides in the *six-two* position, in the *wei* hour, dwelling within the earth’s center yet to emerge. At this time, punishment abides in the Bright Hall, its qi within, while virtue’s qi is without. The teeming living things all delight in exposing themselves and returning to flourishing virtue. In the seventh month, punishment resides in the *six-three* position, in the *shen* hour, abiding in the courtyard. The myriad things dare not enter and firmly delight in dwelling outside.

In the eighth month, punishment resides in the *six-four* position, in the *you* hour, not yet reaching the Heavenly boundary. At this time, virtue abides at the gate, and all things delight in peering from the gate, rejoicing in entering and following virtue to return. In the ninth month, punishment resides in the *six-five* position, atop the *xu* hour, reaching the center. At this time, punishment abides in the pathways, and none of the myriad things fail to perish by dawn, following virtue to conceal themselves. Thus, the inner realm flourishes daily, while the outer is empty and desolate.

In the tenth month, punishment resides in the *six-six* position, in the *hai* hour, extending to the six distant boundaries, eight frontiers, and four wilds. The teeming living things all conceal themselves and flee, following virtue’s movement into the Bright Hall. Crawling creatures carry their young within, while the wilds outside are empty of scholars and multitudes. This is not because punishment is favored, but rather that those who employ it are seen as perverse. Yet if the heart inwardly harbors punishment to govern the multitudes, their numbers dwindle daily.

In the fifth month, harboring one measure of punishment within causes one group of the multitudes to rebel. In the sixth month, harboring two measures of punishment causes two groups to rebel. In the seventh month, harboring three measures causes three groups to rebel. In the eighth month, harboring four measures causes four groups to rebel. In the ninth month, harboring five measures causes five groups to rebel. In the tenth month, harboring six measures causes the multitudes of the six directions to rebel. Thus, the outer realm is utterly empty of all things, all fleeing inward—this is the manifest proof.

Therefore, governance through punishment appears reverent outwardly but harbors rebellion within, so the multitudes diminish daily. Conversely, in the eleventh month, harboring one measure of virtue within draws one group of the multitudes inward. In the twelfth month, harboring two measures draws two groups inward. In the first month, harboring three measures draws three groups inward. In the second month, harboring four measures draws four groups inward. In the third month, harboring five measures of flourishing Yang virtue draws five groups of worthy ones inward. From the fourth month onward, the six virtues cause all things to emerge and appear, and none fail to teem and return, both within and without. This is the manifest model of Heaven’s Bright Hall.

In the second and eighth months, virtue and punishment are evenly matched, so the myriad things are half-damaged by cold. Punishment daily harms and kills, inspiring dread and fear, and thus fails to win the people’s strength. The sages of antiquity ruled through virtue and the Dao, not through physical force or punishment. They established models and laws, setting forth teachings and decrees for emperors and kings to follow in governance.

When the kingly Way is about to flourish, it takes its model from virtue; when it is about to decline, it takes its model from punishment. In establishing laws and institutions for emperors and kings, one must first clarify Heaven’s intent, inwardly illuminating the Dao of Yin and Yang—then Great Peace will arrive.

The Heavenly Master thus joins with the August Heaven and Earth, constantly concentrating their essence and thought, their hearts deeply attuned to Heaven and Earth’s intent, like overlapping compasses or interlocking squares, not deviating even by a hair’s breadth. Knowing what Heaven and Earth constantly sorrow over, and foreseeing their great taboos—what are these?

The spirits of Heaven and Earth deeply lament and suffer from people’s disobedience and lack of filial piety. What does this mean? Within Heaven and Earth, the three qi of harmonious balance unite as one family to nurture the myriad things. Heaven governs life and is called Father; Earth governs nurturance and is called Mother; humanity governs governance and is called Child. The Child receives the mandate from the Father and is lovingly nurtured by the Mother. As a child, one must respectfully serve the Father and love the Mother—what does this mean?

The Father’s teachings have their measures and seasons, so he instructs and brings forth life in accordance with the four seasons. Wicked people oppose the Father’s intent, causing Heaven’s qi to lose its governance. This is like a household where the father is angry with his child, and father and child are at odds. Yin overcomes Yang, the lower deceives the upper, ministers neglect their duties, and demonic forces flourish. The positions of Heaven and Earth are like the distinction between male and female in humans—their likes and dislikes are the same. Heaven nurtures human life, and Earth nurtures human form.

This is the luminous decree of August Heaven, by which the governance of human rulers is judged, and the effects of success or failure are made manifest.

chunks.original_text: 今凡共贼害其父母。 四时之炁，天之按行也，而人逆之，则贼害其父。 以地为母，得衣食养育，不共爱利之，反贼害之。 人甚无状，不用道理，穿凿地，大兴土功，其深者下及黄泉，浅者数丈。 独母愁患，诸子大不谨孝，常苦忿忿悃悒，而无从得道其言。 古者圣人时运，未得通其天地之意，凡人为地无知，独不疾痛而上感天，而人不得知之。 故父灾变复起，母复怒不养万物，父母俱怒，其子安得无灾乎。 夫天地至慈，唯不孝大逆，天地不赦，可不哉。 大起土，大灾起，小起土，小灾起，是地忿，使神灵生此灾也。 或起土不便为灾者，得良善地也。 即灾者，得凶恶地也。 主能害人，并害远方，何谓也？ 比若良善之人，虽见冤害，强忍须臾，心终不忘也。 恶人不能忍须臾，便见灾害也。 地体巨大，人比於地积小，所穿凿安能为害也？ 然比夫人躯长一丈，大十围，其齿齲间虫，小小不足道。 食人齿，大疾当作之时，其人啼呼久久，齿为之坠落悉尽。 人比於天地，大小如此虫与人矣。 齿若金石之坚者，小虫但肉耳，而害物若此。 今有大丈夫巨力之士，无不能制蚧虫者，一升蚧虫共蚀，此人乃病痛不得卧，剧者着床。 今蛄虫蚤虱小小，积众多，共食人，蛊虫者能杀人，蚤虱同使人烦满，不得安坐，皆生疮耳。 人之害天地，亦若是耳。 穿地见泉，地之血也； 见石，地之骨也； 土，地之肉也。 取血破骨穿肉，复投瓦石坚木於地中为疮。 地者，万物之母也，而患省若此，岂得安乎？ 凡人居母身上，亦有障隐多少。 穿地一尺，为阳所照，炁属天； 二尺者，物之所生，炁属中和； 三尺者，及地身阴，过此已往，皆伤地形也。 平道德，价数贵贱，解通愚人心。 今一旦赐子千斤之金，使子与国家，宁得天地之欢心，以调阴阳，使灾异尽除，帝王老寿，治致太平邪？ 今赍万变之璧，以归国家，宝而藏之，此天下珍物也。 宁使六方太和之炁尽见，瑞应悉出，夷狄却去，万里不为害。 吾所以告子道毕具，乃能使帝王保得天地之欢心，天下群神徧说，蚑行动摇之属，莫不悦喜，夷狄却降，瑞应悉出，灾害悉除，国家延命，人民老寿。 审能好善，行吾书，惟思其要意，莫不响应。 比若重规合矩，无有脱者也。 欲与国千斤金，不若与一要言，以致治太平，除灾安天下。 古者帝王未常患财货，乃患贫於〔士〕，愁大贤不至，人民〔不〕聚，皆欲外附，日以疏少，以是不称皇天之心。 若积金玉奇物，纵横千里，直上至天，终不致大贤圣人仙士来，赖助帝王之治。 吾书乃三光神吏，常随而照之。 夫上之臣子民之属，其为行也，常旦夕忧念其君王也。 念欲安之心，正为其疾痛，常乐帝王垂拱而自治也，其民臣莫不象之而孝慈也。 上得天心，下得地意，中央使万民莫不惧心，无有冤结，蚑行之属莫不向风而化，万物各得其所，天地和悦，人君为增寿，上老至于婴儿，不知复为恶天下，且惜其君恐老，天地必使神人持负灵药，告之帝王服之，寿无穷矣。 何为上善臣子之行也？ 上善第一孝子之行者，念其父母且老去，独居闲处念思之，於何得不死之术以奉亲。 贱财贵道活而已，思弦歌以乐其亲，风化其意，使入道也。 乐终古与居，不知老也。
chunks.translated_text:
Now, all who jointly harm their Father and Mother—how is this so?

The qi of the four seasons is Heaven’s governance in motion, yet people oppose it, thus harming their Father. Earth is their Mother, from whom they receive clothing, food, and nurturance; yet instead of loving and benefiting her, they turn to harm her. Human conduct is most unseemly, defying all reason. They bore into the earth, launching vast earthworks—some digging deep to the Yellow Springs, others several fathoms down. The Mother alone grieves in sorrow, while her many children, utterly lacking in filial reverence, constantly vex her with resentment and stifled distress, yet she has no means to voice her plight. In ancient times, the sages moved with the seasons, yet even they could not fully grasp the intent of Heaven and Earth. Ordinary people, ignorant of the earth, do not perceive her pain and suffering, nor do they sense her influence upon Heaven. Thus, when the Father’s calamities recur, the Mother grows wrathful and ceases to nurture the myriad things. When both Father and Mother are enraged, how can their children escape disaster?

Heaven and Earth are supremely compassionate, yet for the great crime of filial impiety, they grant no pardon—how can one not tremble? Great earthworks bring great disasters; small earthworks bring small disasters. It is the Earth’s wrath that summons the spirits to generate such calamities. If earthworks do not immediately result in disaster, it is because the land is good and kind. Where disaster strikes, the land is fierce and malevolent. The ruler’s harm extends even to distant lands—what does this mean? It is like a good and kind person who, though wronged, endures for a time, yet never forgets the grievance. The wicked cannot endure even for a moment before disaster befalls them.

The Earth’s body is vast, while humans, in comparison, are as small as dust. How can their digging possibly cause harm? Yet consider this: a person stands a fathom tall, ten spans in girth, and in the crevices of their teeth dwell tiny, insignificant worms. When these worms gnaw at the teeth, causing great pain, the person wails for a long time, and the teeth eventually fall out entirely. The disparity between humans and Heaven and Earth is like that between these worms and a person. Even if one’s teeth were as hard as metal or stone, these tiny, fleshy worms could still cause such harm. Now, if a strong and mighty man were powerless to resist a pint of mites gnawing at him, he would be stricken with pain and unable to lie down—severe cases would confine him to bed. Even fleas, lice, and other tiny creatures, when gathered in great numbers, can torment a person, causing restlessness and sores. Parasitic worms can kill, while fleas and lice bring only vexation and discomfort. The harm humans inflict upon Heaven and Earth is no different.

To dig into the earth and reach the springs is to draw the Earth’s blood; to uncover stone is to expose her bones; soil is her flesh. To take her blood, break her bones, and pierce her flesh, then cast bricks, stones, and hardwood into her depths—these are wounds upon her body. Earth is the Mother of all things, yet she suffers such afflictions—how can she remain at peace?

All who dwell upon the Mother’s body have their own hidden vulnerabilities. Digging one foot into the earth reaches the realm touched by the sun, where qi belongs to Heaven. Two feet down lies the realm where things grow, where qi is harmonious. Three feet down enters the Earth’s yin body, and beyond this, all digging harms her form.

To equalize virtue and power, to adjust values and prices, is to open the hearts of the foolish. Now, if I were to bestow upon you a thousand pounds of gold to offer to the state, would this win the favor of Heaven and Earth, regulate yin and yang, eradicate all disasters, grant the emperor long life, and bring about great peace? Or if I were to present a jade disc of myriad hues to the state, treasuring and hoarding it as the world’s rarest gem—would this cause the qi of the Six Directions to harmonize fully, summoning all auspicious signs, driving back the barbarians, and ensuring no harm for ten thousand miles?

I have now fully expounded the Way to you. By following it, the emperor can secure the favor of Heaven and Earth, delighting all the spirits under heaven. Even the crawling and creeping creatures will rejoice, the barbarians will retreat in submission, auspicious signs will appear in full, disasters will vanish entirely, the state’s lifespan will be prolonged, and the people will enjoy long life.

If you truly embrace goodness and practice the teachings of this text, pondering its essential meaning, all will respond as if in echo. It is like aligning a compass with a square—there will be no deviation.

To give a state a thousand pounds of gold is not as valuable as imparting a single essential word to bring about great peace, eliminate disasters, and secure the realm. Ancient emperors never lacked for wealth or goods; what they lacked were *shi*—men of worth. They grieved that great sages did not come, that the people did not gather, and that all sought to attach themselves to foreign lands, growing ever more distant. This is what fails to accord with the will of August Heaven.

Even if one were to amass gold, jade, and rare treasures stretching a thousand miles and towering to the heavens, it would never attract the great sages, immortals, or divine beings to aid the emperor’s governance. Yet this text is attended by the divine officials of the Three Luminaries, who constantly observe and illuminate it.

The conduct of the ruler’s ministers and people should be such that they constantly worry for their sovereign day and night. Their desire to bring peace stems from their concern for his suffering, and they rejoice when the emperor governs effortlessly, while the people and ministers emulate his filial piety and kindness.

When the ruler aligns with the heart of Heaven above and the intent of Earth below, and the central realm ensures that all people are reverent, without grievances or resentment, even the crawling creatures will turn toward virtue. All things will find their proper place, Heaven and Earth will be harmonious and joyful, and the ruler’s lifespan will be extended. From the eldest to the youngest, none will commit evil in the realm. They will cherish their ruler, fearing his aging, and Heaven and Earth will surely send divine beings bearing elixirs to instruct the emperor in their use, granting him boundless longevity.

What, then, is the conduct of the finest ministers and children? The foremost conduct of a filial child is this: when their parents grow old and frail, they dwell alone in quiet contemplation, pondering how to obtain the art of immortality to serve them. They scorn wealth and treasure the Way, seeking only to sustain life. They play the zither and sing to bring joy to their parents, guiding their hearts toward the Dao. They delight in remaining with them for all time, never knowing old age.

chunks.original_text: 常为求索殊方，周流远所，至诚乃感天，力尽乃已也。 衣食才自足，不复为后世置珍宝，反愁苦父母，使守之。 此为上善第一孝子也。 上善弟子受师道德之后，念缘师恩，遂得成人，乃得长与贤柔相随，不失行伍。 或得名位以报父母，或得深入道味，知自养之术也。 夫人乃得〔生於〕父母，得成道德於师，得荣尊於君。 独居一处，念君师父将老，无以可报之。 常思行为师求殊方异文，可以报功者。 或更学事贤者，属托其师，为其言语。 或使上得国家之良辅，有益帝王之治。 若此者，为太古善弟子也。 古者三皇上圣，胜人乃与至道，与德治，胜人不以威严智诈也。 夫以威严智诈刑罚胜人者，正乃寇盗贼也。 夫盗贼专以此胜服人，君子以何分别，自明殊异乎？ 故道德之君，常将严威智诈为盗贼之行矣。 天师书辞，常有上皇太平炁且至，何谓也？ 夫圣人制法，皆象之意也，守一而乐上卜。 卜者，问也。 常乐上行而卜问不止，最上之路也。 故上字一画直上而卜，下为字一下而卜，卜问也。 常思念问，下行者极无下，故乐下益者，不复得上也。 皇字者，一日而王。 上一者，天数，得一，得日照，然后大明，则为王。 一与日王合，而成皇字也。 一为天，天亦君也。 日，君德也，王亦君长也，三君长共成皇，言盛德煌煌，天下第一，无复能上者也。 太者，大也。 言其积大如天，无有大於天者。 平者，言治太平均，凡事悉治，无复不平。 比若地，居下执平。 比若人种刈，种善得善，种恶得恶，耕用力，分别报之厚。 天气悦下，地气悦上，二气相通，而为中和之气，相受共养万物，无复有害，故曰太平。 天地中和同心，共生万物，男女同心而生子，父母子三人同心，共成一家，君臣民三人共成一国。 夫帝王者，天之贵子，子承父教，当顺行之，以降天地忧，因得其佑，故常思力行之。 使天文不效者，时有理乱，道不空出。 古者帝王见微知着，因任行其事，顺其炁，遂得天心，意如长吉。 逆之，则水旱炁乖忤，流灾积成，变怪不可止，名为灾异。 众贤迷惑，不知逆顺之道。 使其知之，逢太平，则安枕而理； 〔逢〕中平，则可力而行之； 逢不平，以道自辅而备之。 犹若夏至则备暑，冬至则备寒，此之谓也。 天道有常运，故顺之则吉昌，逆之则危亡。 天道战斗，其命伤； 日月失度，列星乱行。 能用者自力，无敢闭藏贤，明上下，令自安。 灸刺者，所以调和，安三百六十脉，通阴阳之炁，而除害者。 三百六十脉者，应一岁三百六十日，日一脉持事，应四时五行而动出外，周旋身上，总於顶内，击於藏裹。 咸应四时而动移，有疾则不应度数，往来失常，或结或伤，或顺或逆，故当治之。 火者太阳之精，公正之明也，所以察奸除害恶也。 刺者，少阴之精也，太白之质，所以用义斩伐。 治百中百，治十中十，此得天经脉谶书也； 实与脉相应，则神为驱使。 治十中九失一，与除脉相应，精为其躯使。 治十中八，人道书也，人意为其使。 过此而下，不可以治疾也，反或伤。 甲脉有病反治乙，名为恍惚，不知脉独伤绝。 故乐知天道神不神，相应与不也。 直置一病人於前，名为脉本文，比若书经道本文，令众贤而识其病，或有长於上，或有长於下，三百六十脉，各有所睹，取其行事常所长，而治诀者以记之，十十中者是也，不中者皆非也。
chunks.translated_text:
Ever seeking rare methods, they journey to distant lands, their sincerity moving Heaven, their efforts unceasing until their strength is spent. With clothing and food just sufficient for themselves, they no longer amass treasures for posterity, lest their parents be burdened with guarding them. Such is the foremost conduct of the finest filial child.

When the finest disciples receive the Dao and virtue from their masters, mindful of the grace that enabled their growth into adulthood, they remain ever in the company of the wise and gentle, never straying from their ranks. Some attain rank and position to repay their parents; others delve deeply into the savor of the Dao, mastering the art of self-nurturance. All people are born of their parents, attain the completion of Dao and virtue through their masters, and gain honor and esteem from their rulers. Dwelling alone, they ponder how their ruler, master, and father will age, and how to repay them. They constantly strive to seek rare methods and extraordinary texts for their masters, that they may requite their merit. Some further study under the worthy, entrusting their masters to them and speaking on their behalf. Some enable their superiors to become the state’s finest aides, benefiting the emperor’s governance. Such are the noble disciples of the High Antiquity.

The Three Sovereigns and supreme sages of old overcame others through the utmost Dao and governance by virtue, never by might, severity, cunning, or deceit. Those who overcome others through might, severity, cunning, deceit, and punishment are but bandits and thieves. Bandits and thieves rely solely on these to subdue others—how then do the noble distinguish themselves, making their difference clear and manifest?

Thus, rulers of Dao and virtue ever regard severity, might, cunning, and deceit as the conduct of bandits and thieves. The Celestial Master’s writings often speak of the *qi* of the Supreme August and the advent of Great Peace—what does this mean? The sages established laws in accordance with symbolic meaning, abiding in the One and delighting in divination above all. *Divination* means inquiry. To constantly delight in acting above and inquiring without cease is the loftiest path. Thus, the character *shang* (上, "above") is a single stroke rising upward with *bu* (卜, "divination"); the character *xia* (下, "below") is a single stroke descending with *bu*. Constant inquiry and descent lead to the lowest extreme, so those who delight in descending further can no longer ascend.

The character *huang* (皇, "august") means "to become king in a single day." The upper *yi* (一, "one") is the number of Heaven; attaining the One, one gains the illumination of the sun, and with great brightness, becomes king. The One and the sun-king combine to form *huang*. The One is Heaven, and Heaven is also the ruler. The sun embodies the ruler’s virtue, and the king is also the ruler’s superior. These three rulers together form *huang*, signifying resplendent virtue, foremost under Heaven, with none above.

*Tai* (太) means "great," signifying accumulation as vast as Heaven, with nothing greater than Heaven. *Ping* (平, "peace") means governing with supreme impartiality, ordering all affairs so that none remain unbalanced. It is like the earth, which abides below and upholds equilibrium. It is like sowing and reaping: planting good yields good, planting evil yields evil; toil in cultivation brings a bountiful harvest in return. Heaven’s *qi* delights in descending, Earth’s *qi* delights in ascending; the two *qi* interpenetrate to form the harmonious *qi* of the center, mutually receiving and nurturing the myriad things without harm. Thus is it called *Great Peace*.

When the *qi* of Heaven and Earth harmonize as one, they jointly engender the myriad things. When man and woman unite in heart, they bear children. When father, mother, and child unite in heart, they form a household. When ruler, minister, and people unite in heart, they form a state. The emperor is Heaven’s noble child; as a child heeds his father’s teachings, he should act in accordance, alleviating Heaven and Earth’s concerns and thereby gaining their protection. Thus, he constantly strives to act with diligence.

If celestial patterns do not manifest, it is because the times know order and disorder, and the Dao does not emerge in vain. The emperors of old perceived the subtle and knew the manifest; acting in accordance with the moment and following the *qi*, they attained Heaven’s favor, their intentions ever auspicious. To act contrary brings discord between water and drought, *qi* in conflict and opposition, disasters accumulating into unceasing calamities and prodigies—these are called *portents and anomalies*. The multitude of worthies grow confused, unaware of the Dao of compliance and opposition. Were they to know it, when encountering Great Peace, they would govern with ease; when encountering middling peace, they would act with effort; when encountering disorder, they would rely on the Dao to aid and prepare themselves. It is like preparing for summer at the summer solstice and for winter at the winter solstice—this is the meaning.

The Dao of Heaven moves in constant cycles; to comply with it brings prosperity and flourishing, to oppose it brings peril and ruin. When the Dao of Heaven contends, its mandate is harmed; when the sun and moon lose their measure, the constellations move in disorder. Those who can employ it act with their own strength, daring not conceal the worthy, illuminating above and below, and enabling all to find peace.

Moxibustion and acupuncture serve to harmonize and pacify the three hundred and sixty meridians, unblocking the *qi* of yin and yang to dispel harm. The three hundred and sixty meridians correspond to the three hundred and sixty days of the year, each meridian governing a day, moving in accordance with the four seasons and five phases, circulating throughout the body, converging within the crown of the head, and striking within the viscera. All respond to the four seasons in their movements; when ill, they fail to conform to their measures, their coming and going losing regularity, sometimes binding, sometimes injuring, sometimes flowing smoothly, sometimes reversing. Thus, they must be treated.

Fire is the essence of the Great Yang, the clarity of impartial justice, used to examine treachery and eliminate harm and evil. Acupuncture is the essence of the Lesser Yin, the substance of Venus, used with righteousness to cut and strike. When treatment succeeds in all one hundred cases, or in ten out of ten, this is the celestial canon of meridians and apocrypha; when truly in accord with the meridians, the spirits are commanded. When treatment succeeds in nine out of ten, missing one, and in harmony with the meridians, the essence is commanded. When treatment succeeds in eight out of ten, it is the human canon; human intention commands. Below this, illness cannot be treated, and harm may instead result. To treat the *jia* meridian when the *yi* meridian is afflicted is called *delirium*, failing to recognize the meridian’s solitary injury and severance.

Thus, to delight in knowing whether the celestial Dao is spiritually responsive or not is to place a single patient before oneself, naming it the *root text of the meridians*—like the root text of the scriptures and Dao—enabling the multitude of worthies to recognize the illness. Some excel in the upper, some in the lower; the three hundred and sixty meridians each have their insights. Taking the actions in which they commonly excel, the therapeutic methods are recorded: those that succeed in ten out of ten are correct, while all others are not.

chunks.original_text: 集众行事，愈者以为经书，则所治无不解诀者也。 吾道即甲子乙丑，六甲相承受，五行转相从，四时周反始，书卷虽众多，各各有可纪，比若人一身，头足转相使。 一字只遗一字起，贤之次之以相辅，合阴阳以言语，表裹相应如规矩，始诵无味有久久，念之不懈验至矣。 灾害去身神还聚，人自谨良无恶子，为无刑罚，而道化美极也。 明按吾文，以却咎扞祸，祸自止，民自寿，原未得本无终始。 十十相应，太阳文也。 十九相应，太阴文也。 十八相应，中和书也。 十七相应，破乱文也。 十六相应，过中书也。 十五相应，无知书也。 可言半吉半凶文。 十四中者，邪文也。 十三中者，大乱文也。 十二中者，弃文也。 十一中者，佚中文也。 十七中者已下，不可用，误人文也。 随伤多少，还为人伤，久久用之不止法，绝后灭嗣，此为十十文也。 乐得其实者，但观上古之圣辞，中古之圣辞，下古之圣辞； 合其语言，视其所为，可知矣。 复思上古道书，中古道书，下古道书，三合以同类相召呼，复令可知矣。 凡书文皆天谈，何故其治时矣？ 然能其言，正其言者理矣，不正不明乱矣。 正言详辞，必致善也，言凶辞必致怨矣。 欲致善，但正本，本正则应天文，与圣辞相得。 再转应天理，三转为人文，四转为万物。 万物则生浮华，则乱败矣。 天文将出，以考元正始，除其过者置其实，明理凡书，即天之道也。 得其正言者，与天意相应。 邪也，致邪恶气，使天地不谓，万物多失其所，帝王用心愁苦，得复乱焉，故当急为其考正之。 念念从古到今，书悉已备具矣。 神祇之谪人，非同若人得远辟易逃也。 得神祇之心，以解天下之忧，以安帝王，使万物各得其所是。 吾守三实，太平气来，邪伪去，奸猾绝灭。 真人问：天下有几何〔大〕急？ 有几何〔小〕急？ 有几何益祸凶而不急乎？ 神人言：其人宜自精，而具言之。 凡天下之事用为急，不事用者为不急。 神人言：似是而非也。 欲得常急而不可废，废之天下绝灭无人。 理并合无名字者，故为大急。 夫天下大急有二，小急有一，其余悉不急，反厌人耳目，为人召祸，亡家丧国。 若身绝后，坐不急之务，而致此祸患。 若此，夫人生受命之时，与天地分身，抱元气於自然，不饮不食，呼吸阴阳气而活，不知饥渴，久久离神道远，渐失根本。 后生者复不知真道，日流就伪，便生饥渴，不饮不食便死，是大急也。 天地怜愍，共为生可饮食之物，既食且饮，天统阴阳，当见传，不得中统天地之统也。 传之当象天地，一阴一阳，一男一女，然后能生生也。 夫阴极则生阳，阳极则生阴，阴阳相传，比若寒暑，自然之理。 故能相生，世世不绝天地之统。 夫绝天地之统，何有夫妇、父子、君臣、师弟子乎？ 主通天教，助帝王而化成天下，故食饮与男女相须，二者大急。 夫衣者依也，有衣即生贤，无衣则生不肖也。 故衣以御害，故古者圣帝明王，不效玄黄之色，但御寒暑而已。 饮食阴阳不可绝，绝之天下无复君臣、父子之道。 守此三者，以竟天年，传其天统，终者复始，无有穷已。 古者圣人以此为理，其余皆不急，但召凶祸。 夫男者天也，女者地也，衣食者中和，过此三者，其余皆伪之物，非可须为活，反多致祸奸，致理不平，和气不至，天道乖错，为君子重忧。

Gathering the collective practices of healing and deeming those that cure as scripture ensures that none among the treated remain without resolution. My Dao is like the cyclical progression of *jiazi* and *yichou*, the six *jia* phases succeeding one another, the Five Agents turning in mutual accord, the four seasons revolving to return to their origin. Though the scrolls may be numerous, each has its recordable essence—like the human body, where head and feet serve one another in turn. One word omitted gives rise to another; the worthy follow in succession to lend support. Harmonizing yin and yang in speech, the outer and inner correspond as if by compass and square. At first recitation, it may seem tasteless, but with prolonged reflection and unwavering devotion, verification will come. Disasters depart from the body, spirit returns to gather, and people naturally become prudent and free of malevolence, living without punishment or penalty, while the transformative power of the Dao reaches its utmost beauty.

By clearly following my text, one averts blame and wards off calamity; calamity ceases of itself, and the people naturally attain longevity. The origin, having never obtained its root, knows no end or beginning. When ten out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Taiyang*. When nine out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Taiyin*. When eight out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Zhonghe*. When seven out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Poruination*. When six out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Excess*. When five out of ten correspond, it is the scripture of *Ignorance*—this may be called a text of half-fortune and half-misfortune. Fourteen out of ten is a perverse text. Thirteen out of ten is a text of great chaos. Twelve out of ten is an abandoned text. Eleven out of ten is a text of dissipation. From seventeen out of ten downward, it is unusable—a text that misleads people. The extent of harm inflicted will in turn harm the practitioner. Prolonged misuse without cessation violates the law, leading to the extinction of posterity—this is the text of ten out of ten.

Those who delight in attaining its truth need only observe the sacred words of the sages of high antiquity, the sages of middle antiquity, and the sages of later antiquity. By harmonizing their speech and examining their deeds, it can be known. Further, reflect on the Daoist scriptures of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and later antiquity; when the three are united by kindred resonance, it becomes knowable once more. All written texts are the discourse of Heaven—why then do they heal in their time? If one can master their words and rectify their speech, principle is attained; if not rectified, obscurity and chaos ensue. Correct speech and detailed discourse must lead to goodness, while ominous speech and words must bring resentment.

To attain goodness, one need only rectify the root. When the root is rectified, it aligns with celestial patterns and accords with the sacred words. A second revolution aligns with heavenly principle, a third becomes human culture, and a fourth becomes the myriad things. Yet when the myriad things arise, superficial flourishes lead to chaos and ruin. When celestial patterns emerge, they serve to examine the primordial rectitude of the origin, removing excess and establishing its essence. Clarifying the principles of all texts is the Dao of Heaven. Those who grasp correct speech align with the intent of Heaven. Perversity invites malevolent qi, causing Heaven and Earth to lose their harmony, the myriad things to lose their proper places, and emperors and kings to suffer anxious toil, leading to further disorder. Thus, one must urgently examine and rectify it.

From reflection to reflection, from antiquity to the present, all has been fully prepared. The reproaches of spirits and deities are not like those of ordinary people, which can be easily evaded or escaped. By winning the favor of spirits and deities, one can resolve the worries of the world, pacify emperors and kings, and ensure that the myriad things each attain their proper place. I uphold the Three Realities; the qi of *Taiping* arrives, deceit and falsehood depart, and treachery and cunning are extinguished.

The Perfected One asked: How many great urgencies are there in the world? How many minor urgencies? How many things bring misfortune and calamity yet are not urgent?

The Divine Person replied: One should refine oneself and speak in full. Generally, what is put to use in the world is urgent; what is not put to use is not urgent.

The Divine Person said: This appears correct but is not. There are things that must always be urgent and cannot be abandoned; abandoning them would leave the world extinct and devoid of people. Those principles that harmonize and coalesce without name are the great urgencies. Among the world’s great urgencies, there are two; among minor urgencies, there is one. All else is not urgent—it merely wearies the ears and eyes of people, inviting calamity, destroying families, and ruining states. Or it may sever posterity, all from attending to non-urgent affairs and thereby bringing such disasters.

Thus, when a person is born and receives their mandate, they partake of the body of Heaven and Earth, embracing primordial qi in spontaneity. Without drinking or eating, they live by inhaling and exhaling the qi of yin and yang, unaware of hunger or thirst. Over time, they drift far from the spiritual Dao and gradually lose their root. Later generations, ignorant of the true Dao, daily drift toward falsity, becoming subject to hunger and thirst. Without drink or food, they die—this is the first great urgency. Heaven and Earth, in their compassion, together produce things that can be consumed. Yet having eaten and drunk, one falls under the governance of yin and yang, subject to transmission, unable to centrally govern the continuity of Heaven and Earth. Transmission should mirror Heaven and Earth: one yin, one yang; one man, one woman—only then can generation continue.

When yin reaches its extreme, yang is born; when yang reaches its extreme, yin is born. Yin and yang transmit to one another like cold and heat, a principle of spontaneity. Thus they can generate one another, perpetuating the continuity of Heaven and Earth through the ages. If the continuity of Heaven and Earth is severed, what becomes of husband and wife, father and son, ruler and minister, master and disciple? The one who comprehends the teachings of Heaven assists the emperor in transforming and completing the world. Thus, food and drink and the union of man and woman are mutually necessary—these are the two great urgencies.

Clothing is that on which one depends. With clothing, the worthy are born; without it, the unworthy arise. Thus, clothing serves to ward off harm. Therefore, the sagely emperors and enlightened kings of antiquity did not imitate the colors of dark and yellow but merely protected against cold and heat. The continuity of yin and yang in food and drink must not be severed; severing it would leave the world without the Dao of ruler and minister, father and son. Upholding these three, one completes the celestial years, transmits the celestial continuity, and though it ends, it begins anew, without end.

The sages of antiquity governed by this principle; all else is not urgent but merely invites calamity. Man is Heaven, woman is Earth, and clothing and food are *Zhonghe*. Beyond these three, all else is false and unnecessary for life—indeed, it often brings calamity and treachery, disrupts governance and balance, prevents the arrival of harmonious qi, causes the Dao of Heaven to go awry, and weighs heavily on the concerns of the noble person.

chunks.original_text: 六情所好，人不能禁止，因以致祸，君子失其政令，小人盗劫心生，家亡国败，未尝不因不急之物召之。 天下贫困，愁苦灾变，下极欺上，日就浮华，因而愁苦，不竟天年，复使后生趋走不止，山川为空竭，元气断绝，地气衰弱，生养万物不成，天灾变改，生民稍耗，奸伪复生。 不急之物，为害若此，而欲悦耳目之娱，而不悟深深巨害矣。 真人复问神人：孝子事亲，亲终后复事之，当与生时等邪？ 复有异乎？ 事之复过於生时，复不及也。 人由亲而生，得长大，见亲终去，复无还期，不得受其教敕，出入有可反报，念念想象，不能已矣，欲事之过生，殆其可乎？ 神人言：子之言，但世俗人孝之言耳，非大道意也。 人生象天属天，人卒象地属地。 天，父也； 地，母也。 事母不得过父。 生，阳也； 卒，阴也。 事阴不得过阳。 阳，君道也； 阴，臣道也。 事臣不得过於君。 事阴过阳，即致阴阳气逆而生灾。 事小过大，即致政逆而祸大。 阴气胜阳，下欺上，鬼神邪物大兴，而昼行人道，疾疫不绝，而阳气不通，君道衰，臣道强盛。 是以古之有道帝王，兴阳为至，降阴为事。 夫日，阳也； 夜，阴也。 日长即夜短，夜长即日短，日盛即生人盛，夜盛即鬼神盛。 夫人以日俱，鬼以星俱。 日，阳也； 星，阴也。 故日见即星逃，星见即日入。 故阴胜即鬼神为害，与阴所致，为害如此也。 上古之人理丧，但心至而已，送终不过生时，人心纯朴，少疾病。 中古理渐失法度，流就浮华，竭资财为送终之具，而盛於祭祀，而鬼神益盛，民多疾疫，鬼物为祟不可止。 下古更炽祀他鬼而兴阴，事鬼神而害生民，臣秉君权，女子专家，兵革暴起，奸邪成党，謟谀日兴，政令日废，君道不行。 此皆兴阴过阳，天道所恶，致此灾咎，可不慎哉。 师策文。 师曰：吾字十一〔明为止〕，丙午丁巳为祖始，四口治事万物理，子巾用角活其右，潜龙勿用坎为纪，人得见之寿长久，居〔天地间活〕#1而已。 治百万人仙可待，善治病者勿欺殆，乐乎长安市，使人寿若西王母，比若四时周反始，九十字策传方士。 真人请问神人：前所赐不达之生策书九十字，未知趋向义理所归，愿为一一解，以遗后世，贯结而不忘。 神人言：为子直解之。 师曰：吾字十一明为止。 师者，正谓皇天神人师也。 曰者，辞也。 吾乃正辞於天，亲见遣而下，为帝王万民具陈，解亿万世诸承负之谴也。 吾者，我也，即天所急使神人也。 今天以是承负之灾四流，始有根本后理者，悉皆随之失其政，无从得中断止之，更相贼伤，为害甚深，今天以为重忧。 字者，言今陈列天书，累积之字也。 十者，书与天真诚信，洞相应，十十不误，无一欺者也。 得而众贤者自深计，其先人皆有承负也，谓之不止承负之厄，小大悉且除矣。 一者，其道要，正当以守一始起也。 守一不置，其人日明，天迷解矣。 明为止，止者足也。 夫足者，为行此道者，但日有益，昭昭然，不复愚暗冥冥也。 十一，士也。 明为止者，赤也。 言赤气谓此，当复更盛大明也。 止者，万物之足也。 万物始萌，直布根以本足生也。 行此道，其法乃更本元气，得天地之心，第一最善，政称上皇之道也。 丙午丁巳，火也，赤也。
